settle.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to end an argument or solve a disagreement
settle.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: We hope the factions will be able to settle their differences (=agree to stop arguing) by peaceful means.
Forensic tests should settle the question of whether Bates was actually present at the scene of the crime.
They might be willing to settle out of court (=come to an agreement without going to a court of law).
Rodman met with Kreeger to try and settle the dispute over his contract.
She finally settled with her former employers for an undisclosed sum.
settle.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to decide what you are going to do, especially so that you can make definite arrangements
settle.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: It’s settled then. I’ll go back to the States in June.
‘She’s only 15.’ ‘That settles it (=that is enough information for a definite decision to be made)! We’re not taking her with us!’
settle.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to go to a place where no people have lived permanently before and start to live there
settle.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: This territory was settled in the mid-1850s by German immigrants.
settle.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to go to live in a new place, and stay there for a long time
settle.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Many Jewish people settled in the Lower East Side.
settle.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to put yourself or someone else in a comfortable position
settle.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The dog settled on the grass to enjoy its bone.
A nurse settled the old man into a chair.
Donna did not dare settle herself too comfortably into her seat, in case she fell asleep.
settle.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to become quiet and calm, or to make someone quiet and calm
settle.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: When the children had settled, Miss Brown gave out the new reading books.
She breathed deeply to settle her nerves (=stop herself from feeling worried or frightened).
settle.translation[0].definitions[6].def: if dust, snow etc settles, it comes down and stays in one place
settle.translation[0].definitions[7].def: if a bird, insect etc settles, it flies down and rests on something
settle.translation[0].definitions[7].exa: A fly kept trying to settle on his face.
settle.translation[0].definitions[8].def: if something such as a building or the ground settles, it sinks slowly to a lower level
settle.translation[0].definitions[8].exa: The crack in the wall is caused by the ground settling.
settle.translation[0].definitions[9].def: to pay money that is owed
settle.translation[0].definitions[9].exa: I always settle my account in full each month.
These insurance companies take forever to settle a claim.
He was able to settle with his creditors, and avoid going to jail.
settle.translation[0].definitions[10].de: to deal with all the details of a business or of someone’s money or property, so that nothing further needs to be done
settle.translation[0].definitions[10].ex: When it is finally settled, the Marshall estate may be worth no more than $100,000.
After her husband’s death, Jackie went to the city to settle his affairs.
settle.translation[0].definitions[11].de: if a quality or feeling settles over a place or person, it begins and has a strong effect
settle.translation[0].definitions[11].ex: An uneasy silence settled over the room.
Depression settled over her like a heavy black cloud.
settle.translation[0].definitions[12].de: if a particular expression settles on your face, it stays there
settle.translation[0].definitions[12].ex: A disapproving frown settled on her face.
settle.translation[0].definitions[13].de: if your stomach settles, or if something settles it, it stops feeling uncomfortable or making you sick
settle.translation[0].definitions[13].ex: Georgia had taken pills to settle her stomach, but she was still throwing up every hour.
settle.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Every effort was made to settle the dispute, without success.
The city will pay $875,000 to settle the lawsuit.
It is the area of pricing which may settle the question of which to buy.
The two recently met to settle their differences.
The case was finally settled by the Appeal Court.
She talked to a lawyer and settled out of court with her former employer.
settle.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to end an argument by agreeing to do something
settle.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The two companies signed a pact that settled the patent suit.
Before the second phase of the trial, the company settled out of court (=ended the argument without having to go to court).
The bankruptcy trustee ultimatelysettled thedispute with shareholders.
settle.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if prices on a market settle, they stop rising or falling and stay at a particular level for a period of time
settle.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Crude oil futures prices settled lower in light trading.
settle.translation[1].definitions[2].def: to pay money that is owed
settle.translation[1].definitions[2].exa: Proceeds from the sale will be used to settle debt to other creditors.
Credit cards are one of the best ways of settling bills when you travel abroad.
